how do you decide whether to use the # or b version of the same note

the scale is supposed to use all the letters. so in the key of D, you use the F# note instead of calling it Gb because otherwise there would be 2 G's and no F's. this theory is simple when playing with keys close to the center of the circle, and when playing simple music that mainly stays in scale. if the music gets crazier, it starts to matter less. and as you get to keys close to no-mans-land (6 flats or sharps) the rules also start to break down, and matter less, kind of like calculating time differences between new zealand and hawaii

Looking back at the description of the Japan video, you said there was 1 day on temp narration and then on to the graphics, and then jingles. Just so I'm clear, are you currently on graphics?

that's not quite what it was, but i am still not on the real 'graphics' phase. the current phase i'm still on (and will hopefully be done with in about 12 more hours!!) is kind of like a pre-graphics phase. call it 'pictures', call it 'image collection', call it 'graphics planning', call it 'phase 2', i can't figure out what to call it, and it doesn't really matter. but it involves taking what the words are, and then figuring out what exactly i am going to put in the graphics. like what am i gonna put on screen if i said *this.* a picture is worth a thousand words so it takes longer than you think. plus accuracy is really important. if an i say an earth quake happened in russia, i'm not just going to throw the earth quake in the middle of russia, i need to put it right where it actually happened. so phase 2 deals with all that stuff. including occasional re-writes, as i sometimes will realize that something in the script may be wrong or not work, and have to change it. all the re-writes are rock solid now, and another part of phase 2 is also done (which i can't really talk about right now, and is heavily related to graphics) and now i'm just finishing with pictures, at the 14 min mark as of today, moving roughly a second per minute (which is way up from before, i am setting timers every hour to track my progress and always find new techniques to really push it to the limit) but i will definitely be done with phase 2 like tomorrow. then i will lay down a temp narration for timing, and do temps for all the jingles, and put them in place so i have something to work over, and then do the real actual graphics, which will be what the video actually looks like. that took 30 days for history of japan, but this video is twice as long. the remaining tasks after that also took a total of 30 more days for history of japan, and again this video is twice as long. however, i have set a deadline for the entire video, which is approximately 33 days from now. as you can see there is a huge discrepancy from reality here. but that is how this needs to be approached. the deadline is causing me to think differently, and it is thrilling, and will at least cut the remaining production time in half, even if not the required 1/4x that would be needed to meet the deadline which is surely impossible but as i said i am still taking it seriously, i hope that answers your question

You might be asked like thirty times before you write a response but in case you haven't, Vine had just announced that they are discontinuing their service in the coming months. They'll keep old videos online. I remember back before History of Japan you were kinda in a love-hate relationship with Vine because it allowed you to trim and really concentrate your content, but doing so was kinda addicting(?) in a way and it sorta stagnated you from making longer videos until you made the bold move to cut Vine off entirely during HoJ production. I'm sorry if this question seems to be spiraling out of control or maybe I'm just rambling, but I'm curious to understand why Vine was an appealing outlet for your content at the time and if you've "grown out" of it and don't mind the discontinuation too much or if you still have some fondness for that service. Thanks for reading, regardless!

i was already making short videos (because it was a good way to get used to making videos), and about a year into it i found out there was a popular platform where the videos were supposed to be short, and they are auto-looped. so it seemed like a good decision to try to get the videos onto there. by the time i actually got most of them on there i was really getting ready to get Off the 5-day schedule and start looking at longer stuff. but then the popularity kicked in on vine (but still not so much on yt because vine doesn't let you put links to anywhere!!), so i had to do more short ones, just when i was really ready to do longer ones. so i had to sort of bend over backwards to condense the 7 day vine production down to as quick as possible to have enough time to try some long stuff, and after 3 months i finally finished one which actually did very well, and within a couple weeks i was doing better outside of vine than on vine. so by that point, not only have i made 200 more short videos than i ever really intended to, now i have a whole new audience which actually gets mad at me for doing short videos. so that's 2 reasons it's time to shift. don't get me wrong, i will still do things of all lengths and types. the original reason i did short things is because i like to do things of all different lengths, and i always wrote things of all different lengths, but the short ones are the quickest to produce, so i always fell into the trap of producing the short ones first, early on, because it is really the only way to get started

When you were working hard making 7 new Vines a week and then you started doing them even at a faster pace, do you have some regrets about it, do you feel some videos felt rushed or that quality suffered from the high production and output rate ?

actually no. being forced to work fast  is actually a huge blessing. creativity is so flexible, it is amazing the kind of decisions that you make when you have a deadline-- corners you cut, that you never would have dreamed of cutting if u had no deadline, but under pressure you make crazy decisions and your mind instantly gravitates toward the fast choices, and it also encourages you to gravitate toward more exciting choices to make up for the fact that you can't care delicately for every little thing. an example of one of my most intense time-crunches would be the babies-grownups-babies video. i took so many short cuts, and i was just throwing things in there so fast, and I was almost late for work (i am not telling you what my job is)but in the end, no one is complaining and look at all the stuff i have gotten done.given the demonic flexibility of the creative process, i am really feeling like i never want to work off-deadline again. i mean, I have been working off deadline on this current video for more than 4 months, and i THINK i'm going as fast as i can, but at the same time the video is much less than half done and i still have barely even gotten to the production. this is no way to live. i have a lot of stuff to do, songs, videos, so many things left to do and the years are going to fly by if i don't set some more insane deadlines. which is why i have recently set a deadline for the current video, which is completely unreasonable, and yet it is the best thing that has ever happened to me because it is making me get back into serious mad-crunch mode, which brings a much needed thrill to the never ending landscape of uncertainty of when this thing will ever be done
do you ever miss how peaceful it was before the popularity of history of japan

before that video came out i was working my ass off to keep doing 7 new vines a week, due to their popularity. then out of desperation to make a long video, i started doing the vines even faster, to have time to work on a long video at the same time, and i continued on like that for 2 months, and then finally left vine behind in order to do a mad month-long push to get the japan video done, working day and night, while people kept asking why i had 'stopped' making videos.  which actually reminds me a lot of how things are going now

When you record as the Bill Wurtz Fake Jazz Ensemble, do you always record your tracks in the same order (for instance keyboards first, then drums, etc.)? If so, what is the order? If not, why not?

the whole thing started as a reading exercise, and originally it was usually just whole notes on the chords, and then the melody, sometimes even without drums or anything. but later on i started doing more like a 4 piece arrangement, and mostly now it goes percussion first, (then possibly another track of bigger drums, like kick/snare etc) then chords, then bass, then lead. i know you might think the bass should go before the chords, but nowadays i always do the bass after the chords, for some reason it works better that way. drums always first, but actually percussion before drums, which might seem backwards, but i discovered that percussion before drums actually works better for some reason

Why do you balk at classifying things? Do you not see the traits and methods of execution that cause things to be similar enough to be considered "in a genre"?

you can classify anything, in any way, for any reason. that's part of the fun. there are infinite categories, and you can make up the categories. and they are ever-changing. the lines will always blur, rightfully so. in fact it seems to me that it's hard to really do anything inspiring unless you are blurring someone's line, somewhere. genre naming is (and should be) way way too fluid and elastic for me to ever be able to feel comfortable with a question like 'what genre do you prefer.' to me, favorite-genre questions actually feel the same as 'what race of people do you prefer.' it just seems to crush the entire spirit of life when you look at it that way. i hope that makes sense

When you say you've edited parts of the video, are you editing the script first before moving on, or are you working on the video and saying "this portion of the script should be trimmed"?

i'm on 'phase 2' or the 'plan' stage, or 'pre-graphics', i am not sure what to call it. a lot of the graphic work actually gets done during this stage, it's basically like figuring out how the hell i am actually going to display on the screen what i just said in the script, and it actually inolves doing a lot more research, like nailing down exact geography specifics so i can show them on the map, or finding the images of people, etc etc. Like if i said "and then the clowns took over" ... a picture is worth a thousand words, so that may be fine for the script, but in order to show it on screen i have to know which clowns, i have to know what they were supposed to look like, i have to know exactly where they took over, so that often involves doing more research. or if i say 'then cheese wiz was invented' ... which cheese wiz was the first cheeze wiz? i can't just show modern cheese wiz and pass that off for the first kind. and a lot of times during this stage i may realize that a certain line in the script actually won't work, either because i realize it is innacurate, or maybe just doesn't seem good enough. so little revisions happen during this stage. also as i mentioned, the first draft was way longer than i wanted it to be, so when i do the re-writes i am always trying to say stuff quicker, and so far it is going great. every adjustment i have made has made it stronger and shorter at the same time. the shortening rate is averaging 18%, and i am at about the halfway point of the video

In your song New Canaan, you say that you're going to New Canaan, Pennsylvania, then later rectify that the town is actually in Connecticut (which is true). However, you go on to refer to it as "New Canaan, Pennsylvania" many times after that. Why?

not many times, only once. and there are multiple reasons why. the first reason would be the same reason that it is said that way in the first line of the song -- it is just better melodically. the second reason is because given that it already is that way at the beginning of the verse, the verse naturally wants to end the same as it started. and the 3rd reason it makes sense is that by immediately returning to false details after having explained the real truth, we have now firmly established the recurring theme of incorrect details, which is further developed later. i think if you try singing 'connecticut' in either of the first 2 locations where it's 'pennsylvania' i think you will find that it is not only extremely awkward, but also undermines one of the main concepts of the song

what progress have you made on the video today?

today had some very intense setbacks and yet very intense progress. lately as i've shifted into the beginning stages of production (from writing) the looming magnitude of this project has intensified even more, which is hard to even imagine considering it was already unimaginably intense (the research and writing actually took 12 weeks.) there are endless new challenges, and i saw some particularly technical ones today, relating to processing power, etc. i will need to make small comprimises across the board in order to do anything at a respectable pace. that's about all i can say without going into detail. on the other hand, i had some victories content wise, regarding re-writes and trims. at what is now 5:56, this point was at 7:15 in the first draft. this is good news because i was concerned that the original 22 min draft not only had some tedious and tiresome parts, but it is also not reasonable to ever expect to finish the video if it is that long. getting into the swing of these re-writes, the prospect looks good for actually bringing this endlessly long thing down to a still-very-long but very swift and exciting adventure, and also be feasibly finishable by the end of the decade
